abstract.text: Used by the editor to extend its functionality.

inlineContent.text: Plugins are used by the editor to extend functionality. The most common types of plugins are those which edit a given node or resource type, import plugins and export plugins. See also
to add functions to the editor.

Some names in this class contain “left” or “right” (e.g. .leftUl). These APIs assume left-to-right layout, and would be backwards when using right-to-left layout. These names are kept for compatibility reasons.
This object emits the following signals:

abstract.text: This function will be called when the editor is requested to become visible. It is used for plugins that edit a specific object type.

Override this method to provide the GUI layout of the plugin or any other data you want to be stored. This is used to save the project’s editor layout when
is called or the editor layout was changed (for example changing the position of a dock). The data is stored in the
file in the editor metadata directory.

This method is the same as
, except it draws on top of everything. Useful when you need an extra layer that shows over anything else.

Override this method to provide a state data you want to be saved, like view position, grid settings, folding, etc. This is used when saving the scene (so state is kept when opening it again) and for switching tabs (so state can be restored when the tab returns). This data is automatically saved for each scene in an
file in the editor metadata folder. If you want to store global (scene-independent) editor data for your plugin, you can use
instead.

Types that conform to VariantRepresentable can be stored directly in
with no conversion.  These include all of the Variant types from Godot (for
example
), Godot objects (those that subclass
SwiftGodot.Object) as well as the built-in Swift types UInt8, Int64 and Double.

Abstract base class for input events.
This function is used for plugins that edit specific object types (nodes or resources). It requests the editor to edit the given object.
Enables calling of
for the 2D editor and
for the 3D editor when their viewports are updated. You need to call this method only once and it will work permanently for this plugin.

Override this method to provide a custom message that lists unsaved changes. The editor will call this method when exiting or when closing a scene, and display the returned string in a confirmation dialog. Return empty string if the plugin has no unsaved changes.
This method is called when the editor is about to save the project, switch to another tab, etc. It asks the plugin to apply any pending state changes to ensure consistency.
Minimizes the bottom panel.
Clear all the state and reset the object being edited to zero. This ensures your plugin does not keep editing a currently existing node, or a node from the wrong scene.
Used by the editor to extend its functionality.
Emitted when user closes a scene. The argument is a file path to the closed scene.
Adds the control to a specific dock slot (see
for options).
A control used to edit properties of an object.
Adds a custom control to a container (see
). There are many locations where custom controls can be added in the editor UI.
Plugin for adding custom property editors on the inspector.
Makes a specific item in the bottom panel visible.
A class used by the editor to define Node3D gizmo types.

Hooks a callback into the undo/redo action creation when a property is modified in the inspector. This allows, for example, to save other properties that may be lost when a given property is modified.
